Title: Real Time Ai Driven Assessment and Scaffolding That Improves Students’ Mathematical Modeling During Science Investigations
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets all inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Participants included 70 students across four eighth grade science classes taught by the same teacher from the same school..." (Section 2.1, page 204).
1.2 Context - Source: "Students completed two Inq-ITS mathematical modeling virtual labs during their regularly scheduled classes." (Section 2.1, page 204).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We present the design and initial classroom test of AI-scaffolded virtual labs that help students practice these competencies." (Abstract, page 202).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "In this paper, we evaluate the design of virtual labs in the Inquiry Intelligent Tutoring System (Inq-ITS)..." (Section 1, page 203).
1.5 Education level - Source: "Participants included 70 students across four eighth grade science classes..." (Section 2.1, page 204).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The automated scaffolding appears as an on-screen pop-up message delivered from a pedagogical agent, Rex." (Section 2.3, page 208).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided in real-time based on students' performance in the virtual labs.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "If the student completes the task correctly (i.e., receives 1 for all sub-practices), they can proceed to the next stage. If not, individualized scaffolding is automatically triggered..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is targeted and specific to the sub-practices where students struggle, enhancing their learning experience.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This proactive approach was chosen because students often cannot recognize when to ask for help..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency in feedback timing; feedback is provided based on performance.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students are prevented from moving forward to the next stage if they do not complete the task correctly." (Section 2.3, page 208).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is triggered by their performance.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Individualized scaffolding is automatically triggered based on the sub-practices on which the student was correct or incorrect..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Average of sub-practice scores for each stage.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "To measure students’ competencies, students’ stage scores are calculated as the average of the sub-practice scores for that stage..." (Section 2.4, page 210).

Title: “exceptional Talent and Enthusiasm for Math” an Examination of Storylines Circulated by Chatgpt About Mathematical Learners
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "AI chatbots have garnered increased educational interest since the release of ChatGPT in Winter 2022." (Introduction, p. 1621)
1.2 Context: The context is educational, specifically focusing on mathematical writing feedback provided by an AI chatbot.
1.2 Context - Source: "To understand how AI chatbots participate in such storylines, we examined ChatGPT’s feedback to different learners’ mathematical writing in an exploratory study." (Abstract, p. 1620)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "ChatGPT, an artificial intelligent (AI) chatbot developed by Open AI." (Introduction, p. 1620)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "Data for this study was collected between April and July of 2023 from Open AI’s chatbot, ChatGPT 3.5." (Methods, p. 1623)
1.5 Education level - Source: "When giving feedback under a generalized persona and not 'as a math teacher,' ChatGPT more often focuses on style and vocabulary." (Methods, p. 1623)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The feedback included: 1) greeting, 2) opening praise, 3) discussed mathematical content, 4) worked-out solution, 5) closing praise, 6) offer of ongoing support, and 7) signature." (Methods, p. 1624)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided in a structured format, including praise and discussion of mathematical content, and is tailored based on the learner's characteristics.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The feedback produced by ChatGPT when prompted to respond as a teacher had a predictable structure, which allowed us to easily compare iterations." (Methods, p. 1623)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by ChatGPT reflects existing narratives and biases about different learner characteristics, which may not align with the actual performance of the students.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "While it is unlikely that a practicing teacher would elicit feedback from ChatGPT... it is important for educators... to understand the extent that emergent AI tools have learned to participate in broader storylines about mathematical learners." (Discussion, p. 1631)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily controlled by the AI.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "ChatGPT does not appear to have rewritten, per se, feedback to each new student, but to have modified its previous feedback." (Limitations and Future Research, p. 1632)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified; feedback is generated in response to student input without indication of timing control by students.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified." (Not specified)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: The study evaluates the quality of feedback based on its alignment with existing narratives and the structure of the feedback provided.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We used positioning theory as our conceptual framework... to analyze the data." (Methods, p. 1625)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Not specified; the paper does not detail how agency is measured.

Title: Incentivizing Supplemental Math Assignments and Using Ai Generated Hints Is Associated with Improved Exam Performance
1.1 Primary Stakeholders: Students and instructors in an undergraduate physics course.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The study was carried out at a large public university in the Southwestern United States. The students participating in the study were enrolled in one of two sections... Both sections were taught by the same instructor." (Section II.A, page 3)
1.2 Context: The context is an introductory physics course at a public university.
1.2 Context - Source: "We explored students’ use of optional supports, including supplemental math materials and AI-generated homework hints, and the effects on their exam performance." (Section II.B, page 4)
1.3 Tech/AI type: AI-generated hints integrated into homework assignments.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "AI-generated hints were integrated into the homework assignments, thereby reducing or eliminating the cost to the student, in terms of time, energy, and social barriers or fear of judgment." (Section I, page 2)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The AI-generated hints are offered in all the online homework assignments on kudu.com." (Section I, page 2)
1.5 Education level - Source: "These interventions... are therefore very promising for creating more equitable undergraduate quantitative courses." (Section I, page 2)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "AI-generated hints were integrated into the homework assignments..." (Section I, page 2)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through AI-generated hints that guide students in problem-solving without giving away full solutions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "When a student requests a hint, the AI engine is provided with the text of the entire chapter and the text of the assignment, along with a carefully designed prompt instructing the AI to refrain from giving the full solution to the problem." (Section II.B, page 5)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by AI-generated hints is designed to support student learning by guiding them through problem-solving processes rather than providing direct answers.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "They are meant to guide students in the problem-solving process instead of completely giving away the answer." (Appendix B, page 10)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency in feedback timing; students can request hints but do not control when they receive them.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students have unlimited attempts to use them for each question so that they can explore the most useful version." (Section II.B, page 5)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; they can request hints as needed.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students have unlimited attempts to use them for each question..." (Section II.B, page 5)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Exam scores and completion rates of supplemental math assignments.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "Throughout the three periods of this study, we collected data on student homework scores, use of AI-generated hints on the homework problems, and completion of supplemental math materials." (Section II.A, page 4)

Title: Large Scale Assessments for Learning a Human Centred Ai Approach to Contextualizing Test Performance
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The resulting process profiles could provide insights, uncover new knowledge, and contextualize performance for large-scale state, national, or international assessments." (Introduction, p. 230)
1.2 Context - Source: "Large-scale assessments play a key role in education: educators and stakeholders need to know what students know and can do..." (Introduction, p. 229)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Human-centred AI (HAI) and machine learning techniques.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We leveraged machine learning techniques (including supervised, unsupervised, and active learning) and experimented with a general human-centred AI approach..." (Introduction, p. 229)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "Using the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) data as an illustration..." (Introduction, p. 229)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The released National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) Grade 8 mathematics data were used to illustrate our proposed approach." (Introduction, p. 229)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The proposed framework has the potential to analyze other complex educational data at scale in order to generate data insights and provide rich feedback to educators and policymakers..." (Notes for Practice, p. 230)
2.2 Description of context: The feedback is generated from process data and response data to provide insights into students' test-taking processes.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Process data, combined with response data, reflect students’ test-taking processes and can provide educators such rich information..." (Introduction, p. 229)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is contextualized and aims to improve understanding of student performance beyond mere scores.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "However, a performance score alone for a student from the assessment may not be enough—educators and stakeholders need to know why some students got low scores..." (Introduction, p. 229)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily for educators and policymakers.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The findings may help to prepare intervention if necessary." (Introduction, p. 229)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified."
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Performance scores and process profiles.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The resulting process profiles could provide insights, uncover new knowledge, and contextualize performance..." (Introduction, p. 229)

Title: Effectiveness and Guidance of Artificial Intelligence Chatbots in Diagnosing Exponential Expression Errors
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The study reveals that chatbots may encounter difficulties in detecting and correcting conceptual misunderstandings... the study recommends the integration of synchronous and asynchronous classroom environments in which teachers can closely monitor student responses." (Abstract, p. 547)
1.2 Context - Source: "This study aims to examine students’ learning errors related to exponential expressions and to explore the underlying causes of these errors." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "The primary rationale for selecting ChatGPT and Gemini in this study lies in the fact that both models are current, powerful, widely accessible, and possess distinct technical capabilities." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The findings indicate that both ChatGPT-4 and Gemini were partially successful in identifying and correcting students’ misconceptions." (Abstract, p. 547)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The items in the administered test cover learning outcomes related to exponential expressions in the 8th-grade mathematics curriculum." (Data collection tool, p. 553)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The study investigates the potential of generative AI-based chatbots... to identify students’ misconceptions regarding exponential expressions and to guide them in correcting these misconceptions." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
2.2 Description of context: Chatbots analyze student responses and provide feedback based on misconceptions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Students were asked to share their solutions for each question with AI-supported chatbots and to proceed based on the feedback they received from the bots." (Method, p. 553)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by the chatbots is sometimes effective but can also be misleading.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "While ChatGPT-4 demonstrated the ability to accurately classify student responses and provide effective guidance in many cases, it was also observed to occasionally misclassify answers and provide incorrect guidance." (Findings regarding the guidance provided by ChatGPT-4, p. 558)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency in controlling feedback timing.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students were required to input the test questions manually during the interaction." (Data collection and analysis, p. 554)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified." (Not applicable)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Classification of student responses into categories such as correct knowledge, lack of confidence, lack of knowledge, and misconception.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The classification criteria for student responses were developed by considering the potential types of responses students might give." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)

Title: Enhancing Formative Assessment in Statistics Through Classroom Action Research
1.1 Primary Stakeholders: Students and instructors in a higher education statistics class.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The formative assessments developed were administered asynchronously, where students were initially given 7 days to answer each activity at their convenience." (Methods and action plan)
1.2 Context: A higher education statistics class during the COVID-19 pandemic, utilizing online learning modalities.
1.2 Context - Source: "This study is rooted in my multi-disciplinary three-unit statistics class at a private higher education institution in the Philippines." (Context of the study)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "One of the web-based technologies is the Learning Management System (LMS), which is intended to improve education delivery by assisting instructors in managing activities online." (Introduction)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We opted for adopting MyOpenMath as our platform primarily because it has all the functions we needed." (Methods and action plan)
1.5 Education level - Source: "This study is rooted in my multi-disciplinary three-unit statistics class at a private higher education institution in the Philippines." (Context of the study)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "We deemed it necessary to incorporate immediate feedback per item in the formative assessment that we were designing." (Action implementation: formative assessment development)
2.2 Description of context: The feedback is provided immediately after each question is answered, allowing students to see whether their answer is correct or incorrect.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Each formative assessment was programmed to give feedback immediately every time a student entered his/her answer as a right or wrong indicator per item." (Action implementation: formative assessment development)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is effective as it encourages students to identify mistakes and motivates them to improve their understanding.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The immediate feedback setup... did not only serve to inform students about their scores, but it became a stimulus for them to take risks, identify their mistakes, and challenge them to get the correct answer." (Results and discussion)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students can attempt questions multiple times and manage their time effectively.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "A student mentioned that this is a great improvement because the provision to complete the assessment fragmentally aided them in ‘managing their time’." (Results and discussion)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have control over the timing of feedback as they can attempt questions at their convenience.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The formative assessments developed were administered asynchronously, where students were initially given 7 days to answer each activity at their convenience." (Methods and action plan)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Student reflections, average number of attempts, and time spent per attempt.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We note the average number of attempts and average time students spent per attempt in the formative assessments through the data analytics of MyOpenMath." (Results and discussion)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through student reflections and their ability to manage their learning process.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Students expressed that they appreciate that they can partially answer the activity, take a break, and return to where they left off." (Results and discussion)

Title: Algebra Error Classification with Large Language Models
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "This component enables teachers to provide personalized feedback at scale, since they can write feedback once that applies to many students." (Introduction, page 2)
1.2 Context - Source: Not specified
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a method that overcomes the above limitations by using pre-trained Large Language Models (LLMs) for algebra error classification." (Contributions, page 3)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The dataset contains logs of students’ step-by-step responses to questions in an Algebra I course... recorded during student interactions with an ITS named Cognitive Tutor." (Experimental Evaluation, page 8)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We consider a question from an introduction to algebra class." (Methodology, page 4)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "This component enables teachers to provide personalized feedback at scale... the feedback can direct a student to the precise error in their problem solving process." (Introduction, page 2)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated based on error classification of student responses.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Once detected, the error class then informs the feedback generator which feedback is appropriate to provide to the student." (Introduction, page 2)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is immediate and tailored to specific errors identified in student responses.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This direct, timely feedback enables immediate learning and helps students refine their math skills at their own pace." (Introduction, page 2)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is predefined and based on error classification.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The feedback messages vary in length from short hints, such as 'Check your sign.' to more descriptive feedback." (Experimental Evaluation, page 8)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified" (Not specified)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Classification accuracy.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "For error classification, our primary metric is classification accuracy, i.e., percentage of correctly predicted classes in the test set." (Experimental Evaluation, page 9)

Title: The Influence of Ai Apps on Enhancing Mathematics Learning Among Primary Education Students
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets all inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The influence of artificial intelligence (AI) applications on enhancing mathematics learning in primary school students..." (Abstract)
1.2 Context: Classroom and educational settings in primary schools.
1.2 Context - Source: "The instant feedback and interactive resources provided by AI apps contribute to more dynamic and efficient learning and teaching of mathematics for primary school students in Peru." (Abstract)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly influencing how learning is mediated for the younger population." (Introduction)
1.4 Tool/Platform: Various AI applications such as Smartick, Photomath, and Matific.
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We identified that the following applications are used in Latin America: Photomath... Smartick... Matific..." (Results and Discussion)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The enhancement of the teaching and learning process mediated by apps in the field of education leads to the creation of new, scientifically endorsed, effective tools designed to improve the learning of our students." (Introduction)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "AI can also help teachers identify the individual needs of each student and design more effective teaching strategies." (Conclusions)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through AI applications that offer personalized learning experiences and support in areas where students need it.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "This allows students to learn at their own pace and receive additional support in areas where they need it." (Conclusions)
2.3 Our evaluation: The paper suggests that the feedback provided by AI applications is immediate and tailored to individual student needs, enhancing their learning experience.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The implementation of AI tools in mathematics teaching has a positive impact on student performance and understanding..." (Results and Discussion)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency through self-directed learning.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "the influence of technology on the student's self-directed learning, such as the use of apps for solving mathematical problems, fostering autonomous learning." (Conclusions)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have control over when they receive feedback through the use of AI applications.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "This allows students to learn at their own pace..." (Conclusions)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Academic performance and understanding of mathematical concepts.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The results in Science and Mathematics also showed a positive trend from 2009 to 2022..." (Results and Discussion)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the ability of students to engage in self-directed learning and their performance outcomes.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "the performance of students from all socioeconomic strata has improved..." (Results and Discussion)

Title: Stimulating Individual Learning of the Concept of Fraction Equivalence
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Participants were 300 sixth-grade students from secondary schools in Germany." (Method, page 4)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting during a mathematics lesson focused on equivalent fractions.
1.2 Context - Source: "The study was conducted in the first formal learning phase of fractions during regular mathematics teaching." (Method, page 4)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "The experimental group used an adaptive digital learning environment for practice." (Method, page 4)
1.4 Tool/Platform: Not specified by name, but refers to a digital learning environment designed for fraction equivalence.
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The digital learning environment offers individualized adaptive feedback and difficulty levels based on real-time process data." (Method, page 6)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The intervention took place in the first formal learning phase of fractions during regular mathematics teaching." (Method, page 4)
2.1 Feedback term: Individualized feedback, adaptive feedback, explanatory feedback.
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "Immediate individualized feedback and adaptive adjustment of task difficulty can provide cognitive relief and prevent cognitive overload." (Introduction, page 2)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided based on students' performance in real-time, adjusting task difficulty and offering explanations for errors.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The feedback is based on scientific recommendations... which include a combination of positive reinforcement and explanatory feedback." (Method, page 6)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is intended to enhance understanding and engagement, but its effectiveness varies among students.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The results of the present study partly support this claim." (Discussion, page 14)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students can control their learning pace and choose tasks based on their understanding.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students perceive themselves as competent in their ability to cope with the demands of their environment." (Discussion, page 14)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have some control over when they receive feedback based on their interactions with the digital environment.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The digital learning environment... allows students to engage with the learning environment for genuine practice." (Method, page 4)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Performance scores on fraction tasks, engagement metrics derived from process data.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We utilized process data to operationalize a combined measure of behavioral and cognitive engagement." (Method, page 4)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through students' self-reported perceptions of competence and autonomy support.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "We operationalized students’ motivational and emotional orientations regarding mathematics in general as a trait assessment." (Method, page 6)

Title: Improving the Validity of Automatically Generated Feedback via Reinforcement Learning
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The questions cover a variety of number sense concepts including fractions, exponents, rounding, and many others. All questions and feedback messages are written by real math teachers, deployed to real students..." (Section 4.1, page 286)
1.2 Context - Source: "We validate our framework using a dataset of middle school-level math multiple choice questions from Eedi..." (Section 4.1, page 286)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Large Language Models (LLMs) and Reinforcement Learning (RL).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a framework for feedback generation that optimizes both correctness and alignment using reinforcement learning (RL)." (Abstract, page 280)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We primarily use the instruction-tuned Llama-2 7B Chat model... We also show that GPT-4 can evaluate feedback rather accurately using a rubric..." (Section 4.3, page 287)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We validate our framework using a dataset of middle school-level math multiple choice questions..." (Section 4.1, page 286)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "For example, identifying student misconceptions, providing hints, and using encouraging language to promote a growth mindset..." (Introduction, page 281)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated for incorrect student responses to multiple-choice questions, focusing on correctness and pedagogical alignment.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "We propose a framework that both generates and evaluates feedback messages for incorrect student responses to questions..." (Abstract, page 280)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback generated is aimed at being both correct and pedagogically sound, with a focus on improving student understanding.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "We show that our methods significantly increase the correctness and alignment of generated feedback..." (Section 5, page 291)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is provided automatically based on incorrect answers.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Providing students with helpful feedback can be critical to their learning, allowing them to quickly address and learn from mistakes." (Introduction, page 281)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified" (Not mentioned in the paper)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Rubric scores, accuracy, precision, recall, F1 scores, ROUGE-L, and BERTScore.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We report the average of each rubric label in y and the corresponding scores s assigned by GPT-4." (Section 4.2, page 287)

Title: Work in Progress Investigating Chatgpt for Grading Algebra Problems
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable; the paper is relevant to math education and feedback.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The study aims to evaluate the impact of AI-based grading on student learning outcomes, engagement, and grading efficiency while maintaining pedagogical rigor." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting within an algebra course.
1.2 Context - Source: "This study investigates the feasibility of integrating ChatGPT as an AI-driven grading tool in an algebra course through a pilot implementation within a structured learning environment." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "This study investigates the feasibility of integrating ChatGPT, an advanced AI language model, as a grading tool for algebra problems." (Section I, INTRODUCTION)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The Experimental Group, which receives AI-assisted grading with ChatGPT-generated feedback." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The study will be conducted within an undergraduate algebra course, ensuring a representative sample of students." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The Experimental Group, graded using ChatGPT-enhanced feedback." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided after grading student submissions, with structured prompts to replicate classroom conditions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Each prompt includes the algebra problem, the student’s submission, and a request for detailed feedback." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by ChatGPT is intended to be constructive and educational, though its effectiveness may vary.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Evaluations will ensure that AI-generated feedback aligns with best practices in educational assessment." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily instructor-controlled.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The control group, which is assessed through traditional human grading methods." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; feedback is provided after submission.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The experimental group will receive AI-generated feedback, while traditional instructors will grade the control group." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and clarity of feedback.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "Quantitative metrics include: Accuracy: The percentage of ChatGPT’s assessments that match the expected assessment." (Section III, SYSTEM VALIDATION)

Title: Constraint Based Student Modelling in Probability Story Problems with Scaffolding Techniques
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The subjects of the test were students enrolled in the third secondary level in the Egyptian educational system." (Section 8.1, page 196)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting with a focus on probability story problems.
1.2 Context - Source: "MAST is a Web-based intelligent tutoring system for probability story problems." (Section 4, page 181)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) utilizing Constraint-Based Modeling (CBM).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "Constraint-Based student Modeling (CBM) is an important technique employed in intelligent tutoring systems to model student knowledge to provide relevant assistance." (Abstract, page 178)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "This paper introduces the Math Story Problem Tutor (MAST), a Web-based intelligent tutoring system for probability story problems." (Abstract, page 178)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The subjects of the test were students enrolled in the third secondary level in the Egyptian educational system." (Section 8.1, page 196)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: Not specified
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through highlighting keywords and scaffolding questions to guide students in solving probability problems.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "MAST provides different levels of feedback. It starts by presenting a clue to the student by highlighting the related violated constraint keywords that may be misinterpreted by the student." (Section 7.2, page 195)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is designed to be specific and actionable, helping students to identify and correct their misunderstandings.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The highlighted keywords, and the general feedback, are provided automatically to the student upon submission of an answer." (Section 7.2, page 195)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present through self-paced learning and the ability to request hints.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The student may display the sample space elements in textual form instead of in graphical form." (Section 7.1, page 194)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students can control when they receive feedback by submitting answers or requesting hints.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "In case of an error in the event set representation question, the student may request help by requesting a hint." (Section 7.2, page 195)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Paired samples t-test, normalized knowledge gain, Mann-Whitney U test, and power learning curves.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The tutoring effect of MAST has been evaluated empirically using different tests (paired samples t-test, normalized knowledge gain, Mann-Whitney U test, and power learning curves)." (Abstract, page 178)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through student logs regarding their interactions with the system, including the types of assistance requested.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "A student model database stores all the student logs regarding the selected problem types and the presented statements." (Section 6, page 192)

Title: “i Didn’t Understand, I´m Really Not Very Smart”—how Design of a Digital Tutee’s Self Efficacy Affects Conversation and Student Behavior in a Digital Math Game
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "the agent acts as the one being taught while the real student takes the teacher role" (Introduction, page 2).
1.2 Context: The context is a digital math game where students interact with a digital tutee.
1.2 Context - Source: "an educational math game incorporating an agent, which acts as a digital tutee" (Abstract, page 1).

1.4 Tool/Platform: The Squares Family (the name of the math game).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The math game 'The Squares Family' trains basic arithmetic skills related to the base-ten concept" (2.1 The Math Game, page 5).
1.5 Education level - Source: "In total, 166 fourth graders (83 girls and 83 boys) participated in the data collection" (2.3 Participants, page 10).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "the chat always started with a feedback-sentence that expressed the digital tutee's self-efficacy" (2.1.1 The Chat, page 6).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through chat after game sessions, reflecting the digital tutee's self-efficacy.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The chat appeared after every finished game... The chat always started with a feedback-sentence that expressed the digital tutee's self-efficacy" (2.1.1 The Chat, page 6).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism is recursive, where the student infers their teaching effectiveness based on the tutee's performance.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "the direction of the feedback is different... Here, it is the teacher (i.e., the real student) that receives feedback on how well they have been teaching" (1.1 Conversational Teachable Agents, page 3).
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students can control the interaction with the digital tutee.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "the student can teach Lo in two different modes" (2.1 The Math Game, page 5).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided after game sessions.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The chat appeared after every finished game" (2.1.1 The Chat, page 6).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Frequency of responses to feedback and performance on multiple-choice questions.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "the frequency of response to feedback" and "the proportion of correct and incorrect answers given by the student" (2.5.1 Chat Measures and 2.5.2 Performance Measures, pages 11-12).
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the students' interactions and comments during the chat.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "the coding categories and corresponding measures are explained below" (2.5.1 Chat Measures, page 11).

Title: Contextual Factors Affecting Hint Utility
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The system was designed primarily for middle school mathematics and allows teachers to easily create and assign their own problem sets..." (Background section, Page 2)
1.2 Context - Source: "The RCTs in this study were implemented in the ASSISTments online learning system..." (Methods section, Page 3)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "This work aims to further the state-of-the-art in intelligent tutoring systems..." (Background section, Page 2)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The RCT used in the academic year study was identical to the summer study conducted by Inventado et al. (2016) in the ASSISTments online learning system..." (Methods section, Page 3)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The system was designed primarily for middle school mathematics..." (Background section, Page 2)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "Hints, for example, help students recall relevant concepts, identify mistakes, and make inferences." (Background section, Page 2)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through on-demand hints during problem-solving in an online environment.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The treatment group was able to request a series of progressive hints, while the control group was only able to access a bottom-out hint..." (Methods section, Page 3)
2.3 Our evaluation: The paper suggests that the type of feedback (hints) can significantly affect student performance, particularly in different contexts.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Contextual differences influence hint effectiveness." (Conclusions section, Page 11)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency in seeking help.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "It is also important to understand how the context of the learning environment influences the efficacy of such pedagogical techniques." (Background section, Page 2)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students control the timing of feedback by requesting hints.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students assigned to the HE condition were allowed to request on-demand hints throughout the full assignment." (Methods section, Page 3)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Mastery speed, percent correct, total answer attempts, and completion time.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "Table 1 lists seven performance measures that described students’ progression toward completing the assigned Skill Builder." (Results section, Page 7)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the frequency of hint requests and performance outcomes.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Help-seeking behavior can be measured by the frequency of hint requests, bottom-out hint requests, and the problems with hints measure." (Discussion section, Page 11)

Title: Development of a Generative Ai Powered Teachable Agent for Middle School Mathematics Learning a Design Based Research Study
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The three empirical studies involved a total of 320 middle school students and six teachers in authentic classroom settings." (Introduction, p. 2043)
1.2 Context: Authentic classroom settings for mathematics learning.
1.2 Context - Source: "This study chronicles one usability testing and three cycles of iterative design and implementation process of ALTER-M ath." (Introduction, p. 2043)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "This study designed and developed a generative AI-powered teachable agent to support secondary school students' mathematics learning." (Introduction, p. 2044)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We name the generative AI-powered teachable agent for mathematics learning ALTER-M ath." (Introduction, p. 2044)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The participants included 69 sixth-, 80 seventh-, and 63 eighth-grade students." (Findings from the third classroom study, p. 2060)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "This feedback can take various forms, such as quizzes, simulations or real-world tasks that the agent attempts to complete based on the instruction it has received." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided as students teach the agent, reflecting their understanding and effectiveness.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "As students teach the agent, the system provides feedback on the agent's performance, which indirectly reflects the student's teaching effectiveness and understanding of the subject matter." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism is designed to enhance self-regulated learning and engagement through interactive teaching.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This promotes self-regulated learning by involving students in the active teaching of the agent, naturally leading them to organise, monitor and evaluate their own learning progress." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency through teaching the AI agent.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Learning- by- teaching is realised in different formats, such as peer tutoring, where students engage in one-on-one or one-on-multiple tutoring sessions to teach younger or less knowledgeable peers." (Theoretical framework, p. 2048)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students control when they provide feedback to the agent during the teaching process.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students can also compare their accumulated points to peers through a leaderboard, understanding others' engagement and accomplishment." (Design and development of ALTER-Math, p. 2052)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Pre- and post-knowledge tests, usability surveys, and qualitative feedback from students and teachers.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The final study included pre- and post- knowledge tests in a quasi-experimental study design as well as student and teacher interviews." (Introduction, p. 2044)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through students' ability to teach the agent and their reflections on the teaching process.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "This allows students to practice in authentic contexts and receive timely, relevant explanations." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)

Title: Using Large Language Models to Diagnose Math Problem Solving Skills at Scale
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "We recruited 55 K3, 45 K4, 46 K5, and 39 K6 students and asked them to solve the problems based on the PERC framework." (Section 3, page 472)
1.2 Context - Source: "We focus on diagnosing the problem-solving skills of elementary school math word problems." (Section 1, page 471)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a large language model (LLM) pipeline that diagnoses students’ problem-solving skills from their answers at scale in elementary school math word problems." (Section 1, page 471)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "Using GPT-3.5, our pipeline first generates the PERC rubrics for the given math word problem and uses them to diagnose students’ mathematical problem-solving competencies based on their answers." (Section 4.1, page 472)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We developed a problem-solving framework and an LLM pipeline to scaffold and diagnose four primary skills in mathematical problem-solving for elementary school students." (Section 2, page 471)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "We aim to push it further by diagnosing students’ answers to each stage and giving personalized feedback with LLMs." (Section 4, page 472)
2.2 Description of context: The feedback is generated based on the diagnosis of students' answers using a rubric.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The last module provides feedback based on the diagnosis result." (Section 4.1.3, page 473)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is tailored to the specific competencies assessed through the PERC framework.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "According to the combination, our pipeline gives feedback predefined by the math education expert." (Section 4.1.3, page 473)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily instructor-driven.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The expert emphasized the severity of this issue among the current generation of elementary school students who tend to consume media passively." (Section 2.2, page 472)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified." (Not specified)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy of diagnosis results compared to expert grading.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The results demonstrate that our pipeline outperformed baseline models in accuracy according to expert evaluation." (Section 4.2.2, page 473)
